questions.text: In a patient who is 27 years old. TSH levels and unbound t4 were measured. It was found that TSH is low and t4 was high. There were no features of Graves' disease. Also, there was low radionuclide uptake. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Destructive thyroiditis In the question, it is given that it was found that TSH is low and t4 was high This means that there is primary thyrotoxicosis The next step would be finding the features of Graves' disease But the question is given that there is the absence of Graves' disease Hence we have to check whether there is multinodular goitre or toxic adenoma But in a multinodular goitre, there is high radionuclide uptake Hence the answer would be destructive thyroiditis with low radionuclide uptake Destructive thyroiditis is a disease where there is rapid cell damage and destruction of the thyroid gland, the hormone is leaking out here.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A Multinodular goitre in a multinodular goitre, there is a high radionuclide Option: C Subclinical hyperthyroidism This option is excluded because in subclinical hyperthyroidism TSH is low and t4 is normal Option: D Pituitary adenoma This option is excluded because the TSH is normal or increased in the case of pituitary adenoma But in the question, it is given that TSH is low and unbound t4 is high

questions.text: The patient is on type 3 antiarrhythmic drugs for his arrhythmia. The patient was also diagnosed with Graves disease one year back. The patient has recently developed symptoms of weight loss and easy tiring after household activities .what will you do next?

options.label: A
options.text: Wait for it to resolve on its own

options.label: C
options.text: Administer high doses of antithyroid drugs

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Administer potassium perchlorate The patient is on type 3 antiarrhythmic drug for his arrhythmia The patient is a type 3 antiarrhythmic patient This means that the patient should have been taking amiodarone This is also because the clinical signs match the diagnosis of amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis Here the patient was also diagnosed with Graves ' disease one year back this means there is an underlying thyroid abnormality present in this patient Hence this is type 1 amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis Discontinuation of drugs will not have an acute effect because of a prolonged half-life also if you are going to stop the drugs, this is not practical because of the underlying cardiac disorder Hence we have to give potassium perchlorate 200 mg every six hours This has been used to reduce thyroidal iodide content Perchlorate treatment has been associated with agranulocytosis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A Wait for it to resolve on its own Here the patient is having type 1 amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis which is a serious problem when compared to type 2 amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis which will resolve on its own Hence this option is excluded Option: C Give high doses of anti-thyroid drugs This technique of giving antithyroid drugs in high doses was practised before but this was found to be ineffective and this option is also excluded Option: D Perform near total thyroidectomy Near total thyroidectomy causes a rapid decrease in thyroid hormone levels and may be the most effective long-term solution if the patient can undergo the procedure safely but the administration of perchlorate will give resolution of the symptoms Hence that is tried first before opting for surgery

questions.text: The patient was performing the following maneuver. After the performance, the patient was found to have a facial plethora. This patient was diagnosed with goitre one month back. What will you do next:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Surgery is indicated This sign is called a Pemberton sign This refers to facial congestion due to jugular vein obstruction. This has been attributed to a cork effect resulting from the thyroid obstructing the thoracic inlet, thereby increasing pressure on the venous system This is actually seen in substernal goitre Normally in goitre, iodine replacement is sufficient Because of the obstructive symptoms due to substernal goitre, surgery is indicated

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Iodine replacement Iodine replacement induces variable regression of goitre in iodine deficiency depending on the duration and degree of hyperplasia, with accompanying fibrosis, and autonomous function there may have developed. Surgery is rarely indicated, however, because of the obstructive symptoms due to substernal goitre, surgery is indicated Subtotal or near-total thyroidectomy should be performed by an experienced surgeon to minimise the complication rate Option: C. Replacement with levothyroxine This is not a primary therapy in this case Surgery should be followed by replacement with levothyroxine with the aim of keeping the TSH level at the lower end of the reference interval to prevent the regrowth of goitre Option: D. None of the above This option is not true because Option: B surgery is indicated as the correct answer

Extraedge:

Subtotal or near-total thyroidectomy should be performed by an experienced surgeon to minimise the complication rate Surgery should be followed by replacement with levothyroxine with the aim of keeping the TSH level at the lower end of the reference interval to prevent the regrowth of goitre

questions.text: Patient with subnormal TSH level. When palpated the patient was found to have a thyroid nodule. There was the absence of clinical features of Graves' disease and you also do not have any other features of thyrotoxicosis. Focal uptake was seen in the thyroid scan?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Iodine ablation The patient had a subnormal TSH level but when the thyroid was populated it was found to be having a palpable nodule So this is a diagnosis of hyperfunctioning solitary nodule the results suggested by subnormal TSH level, the presence of thyroid nodule a large enough to be palpable and the absence of clinical features suggestive of Graves' disease or other causes of thyroid causes A thyroid scan also provides the demonstrated focal uptake in the hyperfunctioning nodule

Highyeild:

The treatment of choice is iodine ablation because normal thyroid function is suppressed. Iodine 131 is concentrated in the hyperfunctioning nodule with minimal uptake and damage to normal thyroid tissue .relatively large radioiodine doses have been shown to correct thyrotoxicosis in about 70 per cent of patients

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A Surgical resection This option is not the primary therapy however surgical resection is also effective and is usually limited to lobectomy, thereby preserving their function and minimising the risk of hypoparathyroidism or damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve Option: C-Antithyroid drugs Medical therapy using antithyroid drugs normalises thyroid function But it is not optimal long-term treatment and it's also not the primary therapy Option: D- Medical therapy using beta blockers can normalise thyroid function but is not optimal long-term therapy and this option is also excluded.

questions.text: The patient had influenza one month back .treatment was given. The viral report came out to be negative. The patient started to develop enlargement of the thyroid which the patient has not noticed earlier. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Administer NSAIDs This is the case of subacute thyroiditis also called de Quervain thyroiditis or viral thyroiditis Many viruses have been implicated including mumps, influenza etc. The diagnosis of subacute thyroiditis is often overlooked because the symptoms can mimic the pharyngitis The patient was having influenza 1 month back Also, the thyroid enlargement points towards the diagnosis of sub-acute thyroiditis Treatment of choices is to relieve the pain early NSAIDs are enough to control symptoms in any case Hence this is the correct answer

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A Repeat viral assay This option is false because the clinical signs and symptoms of the patient give us the diagnosis of subacute thyroiditis and there is no point in repeating the viral assay Hence we have to continue with the treatment of subacute thyroiditis Option: C administer prednisolone This option is done only when the NSAIDs are not sufficient to control the symptoms Option: D Administer antithyroid drugs This option is also excluded administer anti-thyroid drugs in subacute thyroiditis there may be features of thyrotoxicosis or hyperthyroidism depending upon the phase of illness However, there is no role of anti-thyroid drugs in the thyrotoxic phase of the subacute thyroiditis

questions.text: The patient 42 years is having a single abnormal gland. Some mutations can be noted in chromosome 11. The patient did not have any symptoms of Endocrinopathy. The lab investigation was done. The serum calcium was greater than 1mg per decilitre. And the creatinine clearance was less than 60 ml per minute. What will you do next?

options.label: A
options.text: Since the patient is asymptomatic monitoring is enough

options.label: D
options.text: Total para thyroidectomy with immediate transplantation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Minimally invasive para thyroidectomy Here the patient is having a solitary abnormal gland and there are no features of Endocrinopathy Mutation in chromosome 11 and all the clinical features in the question give us an idea where the patient might be having a primary hyperparathyroidism In the question it is given there, the patient is asymptomatic but the calcium level is greater than 1mg per decilitre and the creatinine clearance is less than 60 ml per litre these are coming under the guidelines for surgery in asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism Hence we have to perform a surgery Surgical excision of the abnormal parathyroid issues is the definitive therapy for the disease Surgical approaches are generally practised now wherever feasible Outpatient procedure with local anaesthesia termed as minimally invasive para thyroidectomy is done

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Since the patient is asymptomatic monitoring is enough Normally all primary hyperparathyroidism patients are asymptomatic But based on the guidelines given for surgery the patient is having creatinine clearance of less than 60 ml per minute and the serum calcium is above normal Hence surgery is the mainstay of therapy Monitoring is done for the following patients Option: C. 99m TC sestamibi scan Recently there has been a growing experience with new surgical strategies that feature a minimally invasive approach guided by improved preoperative localisation and intraoperative monitoring by PTH assays For this purpose, a 99m TC sestamibi scan with single photon emission is used to find the location of the abnormal gland Option: D. Total para thyroidectomy with immediate transplantation In the case of multiple grand hyperplasias, as predicted in familial cases, it poses more difficulties in the surgical management So the surgeons advocate total para thyroidectomy with immediate transplantation of a portion of a removed, minced parathyroid gland into the muscles of the forearm with a view that surgical excision is easier from the ectopic site in the arm if there is recurrent hyperfunction

questions.text: The following image shows a histopathological specimen of a female with an enlarged goitre, weight gain and constipation for the last 6 months. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hashimoto's Thyroiditis The image shows a specimen of the thyroid gland with marked lymphocytic infiltration with germinal centre formation suggestive of Hashimotos thyroiditis

Highyeild:

Histology: Hurthle cells are seen, diffuse parenchymal infiltration by lymphocytes. 4. Anti-thyroglobulin antibodies and Thyroid peroxidase antibodies are present in the serum. 5. Antinuclear factor (ANF) may be positive. 6. May be associated with other autoimmune diseases (SLE, RA, SS [Sjogren's syndrome],) 7. Thyroxine therapy 8. Complication: increased risk of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL), B cell lymphoma

It is also known as Riedel struma, ligneous struma, or chronic invasive fibrous thyroiditis. Classically, it presents as hypothyroidism with a "stone-like, hard-as-wood" non-tender thyroid gland. Option C - Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is an epithelial malignancy showing evidence of follicular cell differentiation and a set of distinctive nuclear features. It is the most frequent thyroid neoplasm and carries the best overall prognosis Option D - A thyroglossal duct cyst is a mass or lump in the front part of the neck that is filled with fluid. While a baby is developing in the womb, the thyroid gland begins at the base of the tongue.

questions.text: A 32-year-old obese female is being evaluated for resistant hypertension. Her BMI is 32kg/m2. An overnight dexamethasone suppression test done shows plasma cortisol 108nmol/L (cut off 50nmol/l). All the following are features of this condition except.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypoglycemia Hypoglycemia is not the feature of Cushing. Rather Elevated blood glucose concentration.and Insulin resistance can occur.

Highyeild:

Clinical Features of Cushing's Syndrome Symptoms due to excess of glucocorticoid The loss of proteins from the muscle in particular causes severe weakness of proximal muscles (Proximal myopathy) The protein collagen fibres in the subcutaneous tissue are diminished so that the subcutaneous tissue tear easily resulting in development of large purplish striae where they have torn apart. Elevated blood glucose concentration. Insulin resistance can occur Mobilization of fat from the lower part of the body with concomitant extra deposition of fat in the thoracic and upper abdominal regions (Centripetal obesity) giving rise to a buffalo torso. The excess secretion of steroid also leads to an edematous appearance of the face. ("moon facies"). Symptoms due to excess of mineralocorticoid Salt and water retention leads to sustained hypertension. Significant K+ depletion (Hypokalemia) Symptoms due to excess of androgen Hirsutism Facial acne Oligomenorrhea Amenorrhea Other Symptoms Psychosis, insomnia, euphoria Osteoporosis

Extraedge:

Episodic hypertension occurs in pheochromocytoma

Solution:

Hyperthyroidism In the picture, there is a trousseau sign present This means carpal spasm may be induced by the inflation of a blood pressure cuff to 20 mM Hg above the patient's systolic blood pressure for 3 minutes This sign is characteristic of hypocalcemia Hence we have to know the causes of hypocalcemia- Option A In the 4 options, hyperthyroidism is not a cause of hypocalcemia It is a cause of hypercalcemia The mechanism behind this is, in hyperthyroidism, there is a primary increase in bone resorption thus increasing the calcium levels and causing hypercalcemia

questions.text: A 35 yrs female came to the hospital with complaints of fatigue lethargy, thinned skin and a puffy face. Her Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) is extensively raised. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypothyroidism Hypothyroidism: The most common cause is iodine deficiency. Autoimmune hypothyroidism is associated with goitre (Hashimoto’s or goitre thyroiditis) Female to male ratio:4:1. In Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, there is marked lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid with germinal centre formation. There is atrophy of thyroid follicles and oxyphils metaplasia. In atrophic thyroiditis, there is fibrosis and thyroid follicles are absent. Marked fibrosis is also seen in igg4-positive plasma cells. It is associated with hla dr3,hladr4 and hladr5 It is associated with ctla4 a t regulatory gene and with type 1 dm, Addison’s disease, pernicious anaemia, and vitiligo. A gene on chromosome 21 is associated with Down’s syndrome. Antibodies to thyroxine peroxidase(TPO) and thyroglobulin. Thyrotropin binding inhibitory immunoglobulin (TBII) measures the binding of antibodies to the receptor. Clinical features: Dry skin, decrease sweating, thinning of the epidermis, hyperkeratosis of the cornea.increased glycosaminoglycans content trap water and give rise to skin thickening without pitting leading to myxedema. Puffy face, edematous eyelids and non-pitting pretibial edema. There is the presence of pallor and yellow tinge due to carotene accumulation. Nail growth retarded, hair becomes dry and brittle and diffuse alopecia. Pt can experience constipation and weight gain, decreased libido, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, and decrease fertility. There is an increase in stroke volume, bradycardia, increased peripheral vascular resistance, diastolic hypertension, pericardial effusion and pleural effusion. It can cause carpal tunnel syndrome and slow relaxation of tendon reflex-pseudomyotonia. Memory and concentration are also affected. There is a presence of low regional activity in the amygdala, hippocampus and pregenual anterior cingulate cortex. Reversible cerebellar ataxia, dementia, psychosis and myxedema coma. Hashimoto encephalopathy: a steroid-responsive syndrome associated with TPO antibodies, myoclonus and slow wave activity.

Highyeild:

Myxedema coma: It is characterized by decreased level of consciousness and seizure and hypothermia. It occurs in the elderly with drugs like sedatives, anaesthetics, antidepressants, pneumonia, congestive heart failure, myocardial infarction, and sepsis. There is the presence of hypoventilation and hypercapnia and dilutional hyponatremia Treatment: levothyroxine i.v bolus dose of 200-500 micrograms followed by oral dose and in hydrocortisone and hypertonic saline.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B . Hypothyroidism: The above pt shows the clinical features of hypothyroidism with raised TSH. Option A . Hyperthyroidism: The pt does not show any features of hyperthyroidism and her TSH is raised in contrast to decrease TSH in hyperthyroidism. Option C . Hyperparathyroidism: There are no features suggestive of defective calcium metabolism. Hence, it is not hyperparathyroidism.

Extraedge:

Treatment Replacement of thyroxine dose is 1.6 microgram /kg body wt,30 min before breakfast. In old age (>60 yrs) the thyroxine dose should be started at a very low dose.

Treatment: Antithyroid drugs: 1. Thalidomides: propylthiouracil, carbimazole. It inhibits thyroid peroxidase, oxidation and organification of thyroid hormone. Propylthiouracil is a hepatotoxic drug. 2. Propranolol: b1 receptor blocker and control adrenergic symptoms and peripheral conversion of active thyroxine. 3. radioactive iodine: progressive destruction of thyroid cells. It aggravates the ophthalmic symptoms. 4. potassium iodide: it is used after total or near total thyroidectomy causing thyrotoxicosis.
